comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content: This photograph was taken on the 10th of August 1901 at The Mall, Waterford at the start of the second days journey on the Great 1,000 mile Irish Tour organized by the Irish Automobile Club (now the Royal Irish Automobile Club at Dawson Street, Dublin). The bearded gentlemen in the middle is Waterford businessman, motoring pioneer and Chairman of the Irish Automobile Club, William GD Goff on his Daimler motor car. Seated beside him with the wonderful facial hair is Col. McGrath, the first motorist in Wexford. To their right is RJ Mecredy (The Father of Motoring in Ireland). Mecredy and Goff were responsible for bring the Motor Tour to Ireland in 1901.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75421485@N08] Bob, fantastic information! Thank you. Don't suppose you could be wrong about the 10th, could you?? We have this as 9th, and if we're wrong, it's the first hole poked in our Year in the Life set... Also, may I just check with you: "To their right is RJ Mecredy" - Which of the gentlemen to the right is RJ Mecredy? Chap at the steering wheel, or the passenger with the cigarette?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content:
First of all the date; we have an original print of this photograph in the RIAC Archive and it's dated August 10th 1901. If its the 10th then the motorists (there were around nineteen of them at this stage) are about to set out on the second day's motoring from Waterford to Cork. It certainly could be the 9th in which case they have probably just arrived in Waterford at the end of the first day's motoring. So there's your choice... I think on balance I would go with the 9th as they look as if they are tired after a long days motoring, and not as if they are full of enthusiasm after a good nights sleep!

RJ Mecredy, Editor of the Motor News magazine, is at the steering wheel of the car on the right. Not sure who the person with him is but I can probably find out as we have several first hand accounts of the Tour, including Mecredy's. RJ Mecredy was invariably known as 'Arjay' and was certainly the 'Father of Motoring in Ireland'. He was responsible for so many motoring milestones here and was beloved by a very wide readership.

The third passenger in Goff's car is almost certainly his chauffeur, 'Milne'. However, the role of the chauffeur was different then to what we understand now. When motoring first became possible in the late 1890s it was, to those lucky few who could afford it, another sporting past-time to add to hunting, shooting and fishing. So, the owner of the car was not going to deprive himself of the sport of driving the car. However, he needed a servant who could serve lunch when a stop was made on a journey or, more importantly, to fix the inevitable punctures that occurred on almost every journey. Hope that helps.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75421485@N08] That really helps, Bob! So, we're perfect on the date. We can keep this one as Friday, 9 August 1901. Thank you for pointing out which of the men is Arjay or R.J. Mecredy and which was Milne. Really love your description of the role of a chauffeur in the early days of motoring!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
